title-group.article-title: A 426-year drought history for Western Tian Shan, Central Asia, inferred from tree rings and linkages to the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans

2MOE Key Laboratory of Western China’s Environmental System, Lanzhou University, China

abstract.p: We have reconstructed the Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI) from 1580 to 2005 for Western Tian Shan, Central Asia, using tree rings of Picea schrenkiana. The reconstruction explains 35% of the actual January–May PDSI variance during the common period 1925–2005. Split-sample validation supports our use of the reconstruction model based on the full period of reliable observational data (1925–2005). Spatial climate correlation analyses with gridded PDSI data revealed that our PDSI reconstruction represents a strong regional drought signal for Western Tian Shan. Dry periods occurred during ad 1614–1628, 1700–1722, 1758–1790, 1806–1833, 1873–1898, 1908–1936, 1943–1951, 1960–1966 and 1973–1988; while the periods of ad 1580–1613, 1629–1699, 1723–1757, 1791–1805, 1834–1872, 1899–1907, 1937–1942, 1952–1959, 1967–1972 and 1989–present were relatively wet. Our reconstruction agrees reasonably well with the dry and wet periods previously estimated from tree rings in Tian Shan. Significant spectral peaks are identified at 2–5, 60.2 and 213 years. Our reconstructed drought is significantly correlated with sea surface temperature in the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans. The linkages to the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans suggest the connection of moisture variations of Central Asia to the westerly circulation and tropical ocean–atmosphere systems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Drought is one of the most frequent natural disasters in Central Asia. The severity and frequency of droughts and other hydroclimatic events are of critical importance to ecology and the livelihood of the people in the arid regions of Central Asia. Water resource management requires reliable knowledge of climatic variability, especially drought on annual to centennial timescales. However, weather stations were not installed in Central Asia before the 1920s. This limits the analysis of long-term climate trends from meteorological records and requires the study of climate history from high-resolution proxy data.

Tree-ring data from moisture-sensitive trees provide one of the best sources of proxy information that can extend our knowledge of the hydroclimatic variability on annual timescales beyond the relatively short instrumental records. Several tree-ring chronologies, as hydroclimatic proxy records, have been developed from Central Asia in recent decades. For example, the variations of surface water resource of Northern Xinjiang over the past 250 years were established by Yuan et al. (1996); Yuan et al. (2001) reconstructed a 348 yr precipitation series in the Urumqi River Basin; and Esper et al. (2001) established the climatic extreme years since 1427 for Western Central Asia. A 1300 yr climatic history for Western Central Asia was presented by Esper et al. (2002). Yuan et al. (2003) reconstructed the spring precipitation day numbers in the Urumqi River drainage over the last 370 years. These hydroclimatic reconstructions make it possible to describe the drought history of Central Asia. However, long high-resolution hydroclimatic records from Central Asia are still relatively rare. An improved tree-ring data network with dense spatial coverage and a long time span for Central Asia is therefore needed to capture drought variability and to provide insights for the prediction of drought.

Climate data from the meteorological stations of Xinjiang indicate that summer and winter temperatures have increased since the 1970s. Contemporaneously, an increasing trend in summer precipitation is registered (Yuan et al., 2004). These trends seem to be the results of climatic shift from warm-dry to warm-wet in northwest China (Shi et al., 2007). Here, we present a new reconstruction of regional January–May interannual to multidecadal drought variability back to ad 1580. The reconstruction is based on the tree-ring width data from the five sites in Western Tian Shan. As shown below, this drought reconstruction is representative of moisture conditions in a large area of the study regions, which increases our understanding of the overall drought history over Central Asia. The objectives of this study are: (1) to reconstruct regional drought variability for recent centuries on the basis of tree rings from Western Tian Shan, (2) to explore how variability in drought reconstruction relates to extensive drought/wet events across Tian Shan using information from existing paleoclimate proxies, and (3) to investigate linkages between this record of drought and atmosphere–ocean circulation of the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans and Westerlies.

sec.title: Sampling and chronology development
sec.p: Spruce (Picea schrenkiana) trees were sampled at two new sites (DSG and NLK) with little evidence of fire or human disturbance in Western Tian Shan (China) for the analyses performed herein (Figure 1). To minimize non-climatic effects on tree growth, only trees with no injury and disease were sampled. All sampling was performed in open stands growing on shallow or rocky soils. At least two increment cores were taken from each living tree that was sampled. Together, the two new sites provide a total of 166 samples from 80 trees. Three additional tree-ring width data from the three sites in Kyrgyzstan were obtained from National Climatic Data Center, USA (http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/): Sarejmek (Schweingruber and Feiertag, 2007a; Wilson et al., 2007), Sarekungey (Schweingruber and Feiertag, 2007b), and Karabatkak (Schweingruber and Feiertag, 2007c). Site information, including latitude and longitude, slope, length of chronologies, and tree number, is listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Map of the sampling sites and meteorological stations in Western Tian Shan, Central Asia.
Tree-ring sites of Schrenk spruce (Picea schrenkiana) in Western Tian Shan, Central Asia.

sec.p: After mounting and progressively sanding to >320 grit, the cores were cross-dated using standard methods (Cook and Kairiukstis, 1990). Ring widths were measured to the nearest 0.001 mm using a Velmex measuring system. The program COFECHA (Holmes, 1983) was used to test the accuracy of our cross-dating of ring widths. We used the negative exponential curve in the ARSTAN program (Cook, 1985) to remove age-related growth trends from individual series (Cook and Kairiukstis, 1990; Fritts, 1976). Series were combined into site chronologies using a bi-weight robust mean function (Cook and Kairiukstis, 1990). All series of the five sites were then merged to develop a new regional chronology for regional climate analysis (Figure 2). Sample depth within a chronology typically decreases back in time and may result in the variance changes of the earlier part of the chronology. Thus, the variance in chronologies was stabilized in the chronology compilation process with the Briffa Rbar-weighted method (Osborn et al., 1997). The ARSTAN program produces three versions of standardized chronologies: Standard, Residual and Arstan. We used the Standard chronology, which contains the common variations among the individual tree core series and retains the high and low frequency variance, presumably in response to climate (Cook, 1985).

caption.p: Plot of the standard chronologies of Western Tian Shan, and its running expressed population signal (EPS), the running series of average correlation (Rbar) and the sample size.

sec.title: Meteorological data and statistical analysis
sec.p: The relationship between tree-ring chronologies and the climatic data was analyzed using the DENDROCLIM 2002 (Biondi and Waikul, 2004). All statistical procedures were evaluated at P < 0.05 significance level. As the growth of tree may be affected not only by the climatic conditions of the current growing season but also by those of the previous growing season (Fritts, 1976), climate data used for the response function and correlation analysis included monthly mean temperature and total monthly precipitation over a span of 16 months (previous June to current September). To reconstruct past climate variation and provide a more regional climate signal, The gridded monthly mean temperature and total monthly precipitation data of the Climatic Research Unit (CRU) was obtained from the KNMI climate explorer (http://climexp.knmi.nl) for Western Tian Shan for 1925–2009 (averaged over 41–45°N, 75–83°E, Mitchell and Jones, 2005). The Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI) data (Dai et al., 2004) for our study area (averaged over 41–45°N, 75–83°E) for 1925–2005 was obtained from the NOAA-CIRES ESRL/PSD Climate Diagnostics branch, Boulder, Colorado, USA, through their web site: http://www.cdc.noaa.gov/.

The distribution of the variance and the signals contained in the drought reconstruction were examined using Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) analysis (Torrence and Compo, 1998). CWT analysis allows the detection of periodic significant signals (waveforms) by expanding one-dimensional time series into two-dimensional time-frequency space. This method allowed the simultaneous representation of the dominant modes of variability (periodic signals) and the variation of those modes over time (Torrence and Compo, 1998). The wavelet function used in the study was a Morlet wavelet with a wave number of six, and the wavelet power significant at the 10% level was tested against a red noise process.

To demonstrate our record’s geographical representation, we conducted spatial correlations between our reconstruction and the gridded PDSI data set for the period 1925–2005. The analyses were conducted using the KNMI climate explorer (http://climexp.knmi.nl).

sec.title: Regional chronology development
sec.p: Descriptive statistics of the standard regional chronologies are shown in Table 2. All chronologies exceed 350 years and one 487 yr old tree was found at the DSG site (Figure 2). The average mean sensitivity (a measure of the interannual variability in tree-ring series) of the chronologies ranged from 0.13 to 0.16, indicating that the ring-width chronologies show relative low interannual variability. First-order autocorrelation ranged from 0.29 to 0.53, which documents that the chronologies contain low-frequency variance generated by climate and by tree-physiological lag effects. The chronologies had high SNR (signal-to-noise ratio) and EPS (expressed population signal), indicating that the radial growth of different trees was responding to common factors (Wang et al., 2008).

caption.p: Chronology statistics for the standardized tree-ring width chronologies used in the study.

sec.p: The correlation coefficient between China and Kyrgyzstan chronologies for the common time interval 1626–1995 was 0.3 (P < 0.001, n=370). Despite a complex mountain terrain and spatial differences in local climate and tree growth, the two regional chronologies showed a common climate signal. Consequently we combined all series of the five sites into a composite chronology.

The composite chronology was correlated at 0.86 with China chronology and 0.68 with Kyrgyzstan chronology, and both significant at the 0.001 level (Table 3). We used the composite chronology (code RC) for our final analyses because it provides a more regional climate signals.

caption.p: Correlations among the three chronologies in Western Tian Shan.

sec.p: We used the expressed population signal (EPS), which represents the degree to which a particular sampling portrays a hypothetically perfect chronology (Wigley et al., 1984), as a guide in evaluating chronology reliability. The chronology used in the drought reconstruction below was therefore truncated to ad 1580, based on the EPS value of 0.85.

sec.title: Climate response analysis
sec.p: Figure 3 shows the significant coefficients for correlations and response functions on monthly scale for tree-ring regional chronology. Previous year’s rainfall during summer (July–August) and winter (December) generally has a positive influence on tree growth in the following year. February–April precipitation also shows a significant positive influence on radial growth. The RC chronology was negatively correlated with July and August temperature of the previous year and April temperature of the growth year, and was positively correlated with June temperature of the growth year. Climate response analysis indicated that the RC chronology was positively correlated with the PDSI from previous June to current year July.

caption.p: Climatic responses of ring width of Schrenk spruce in Western Tian Shan, obtained from response functions (lines) and simple correlations (bars), calculated for the period 1925–2005. Horizontal dotted lines denote the 95% confidence level.

sec.p: To investigate the climate–tree-ring relationship in more detail, we screened the RC chronology in correlation analysis with the seasonal combinations of temperatures, precipitation and PDSI from previous June to current September. Tree-ring widths show significant positive response to the PDSI. The highest correlation is found between the regional chronology and mean February–March PDSI (r = 0.648). In order to cover more months, and give the reconstruction greater physiological significance, the results of climate response analysis indicate that mean January–May PDSI (r = 0.590) was the most appropriate predictand for the drought reconstruction.

sec.title: Drought reconstruction
sec.p: A linear regression model between the RC chronology and mean January–May PDSI for the calibration period was significant (F = 42.12, P < 0.001, adjusted r2 = 0.34).

A split calibration-verification scheme was employed to test the reliability of the drought reconstruction (Table 4). The period from 1925 to 1965 was used for calibration and 1966–2005 for verification; this process was then reversed. Statistics used to test the reliability of the reconstruction models included the reduction of error (RE) and coefficient of efficiency (CE) statistics, the sign test, and the Pearson’s correlation coefficient (Cook and Kairiukstis, 1990; Fritts, 1976). Both the RE and CE are strongly positive for both of the calibration periods, indicating considerable validity in the reconstruction model. The results of the sign test, which describes how well the predicted value tracks the direction of actual data, exceed the 95% confidence level. The results of the statistics indicate that our regression model is valid. PDSI data for the full 1925–2005 period was then used to calibrate the final reconstruction (Figure 4). It explained 35% of the variance in PDSI.

caption.p: Calibration and verification statistics for January–May PDSI reconstruction in Western Tian Shan.
Actual (dark) and reconstructed (grey) January–May PDSI during their common period 1925–2005. The estimation explains 35% of the actual PDSI variance in this common period.

sec.title: The characteristics of PDSI reconstruction
sec.p: The reconstructed and 10 yr low-pass filtered PDSI for Western Tian Shan is presented in Figure 5. The reconstruction contains considerable low-frequency climate variations during the past 426 years. The long-term means of the PDSI reconstruction based on regression is −0.10 for the period ad 1580–2005. According to the reconstruction, dry periods with below-average PDSI occurred in ad 1614–1628, 1700–1722, 1758–1790, 1806–1833, 1873–1898, 1908–1936, 1943–1951, 1960–1966 and 1973–1988. Among them, the interval ad 1908–1936 witnessed the most severe and extended dry episode in Western Tian Shan over the past 426 years. The 20th century was dominated by dry conditions interrupted only by several short humid periods. Periods of relatively wet years are identified for ad 1580–1613, 1629–1699, 1723–1757, 1791–1805, 1834–1872, 1899–1907, 1937–1942, 1952–1959, 1967–1972 and 1989–2005. As used by Akkemik et al. (2005), the values beyond the inner horizontal lines (±1 SD) indicate dry and wet years, and those beyond the outer horizontal lines (± 2 SD) indicate extremely dry and wet years. 12 extremely dry years (1618, 1771, 1775, 1810, 1885, 1895, 1917, 1918, 1919, 1926, 1927 and 1945) and 52 dry years were found in our PDSI reconstruction. The most noteworthy feature in the late 20th century is a clear trend of increasing moisture intensity under global warming, and 1993, 1994 and 2004 rank among the ten wettest years. 1917 (−5.02) is reconstructed as the most extreme dry years.

caption.p: Estimated (thin line) and 10 yr low-pass filter (thick line) values of January–May PDSI. Central horizontal line shows the mean of the estimated values; inner dotted horizontal lines show the border of one standard deviation, and outer horizontal lines show the border of two standard deviations.

sec.p: The results of wavelet analysis indicate the existence of some important cycles for regional drought variability (Figure 6). The century-scale cycle (213 yr) is most significant in our reconstruction. However, this result should be interpreted with caution, as our reconstruction only covers two cycles of this periodicity. Significant multidecadal cycles (0.01 level) are found at 60.2 years. Significant high-frequency peaks were found between 2 and 5 years (p < 0.05).

caption.p: (a) The wavelet power spectrum. The grey contour intervals represent 75, 50, 25 and 5% of the wavelet power, respectively. Black contours are the 10% significant level, using a red-noise (autoregressive lag 1) background spectrum. (b) The global wavelet power spectrum.

sec.title: Growth–climate relationships
sec.p: Water-deficit stress was generally a major limiting factor influencing tree-ring width for trees growing in arid and subarid regions. Above-average moisture during late summer and early autumn may promote storage of carbohydrates and bud formation, thus enhancing growth during the following year (D’Arrigo et al., 2001; Fritts, 1974; Oberhuber et al., 1998). Increased summer (July–August) rainfall can help ease the threat of summer drought. In contrast, evaporation increases with the rise in summer temperatures, which accelerates the already existing water stress. We found significant positive correlations between tree growth and precipitation in February, March and April. The correlation results between ring widths and climate variables also indicated that the late winter- and spring-moisture availability was a major limiting factor for rapid growth of earlywood. Because the precipitation over Western Tian Shan in winter and early spring falls as snow, the positive correlations with February–April precipitation may represent a relationship with snowpack and its subsequent effects on soil moisture (D’Arrigo et al., 2001; Wang et al., 2006). Tree-growth benefits from the former winter and current spring precipitation and snow, which increase the soil moisture content during the early phase of the growing season (Fan et al., 2008). Later on, with increased water vapor from the North Atlantic Ocean (Li et al., 2011; Yang and Zhang, 2008), enough moisture is available to satisfy the water demand of the trees. The positive correlation with June temperature was reasonable, which suggested that significant high temperatures and suitable precipitation of current year summer could increase the radial growth of Schrenk spruce in Western Tian Shan. The PDSI was developed by incorporating monthly air temperature, precipitation, and locally available water content of soil. Therefore, correlations between ring widths and PDSI were higher than for precipitation or temperature alone.

sec.title: Comparison with other proxy records in the Tian Shan region
sec.p: Several moisture-sensitive tree ring width series have been developed from Tian Shan. Chen et al. (2009) reconstructed the August–July precipitation for the Hutubi region in Central Tian Shan, China. Chen et al. (2010) presented an annual precipitation reconstruction (for the period from previous July to current June) for the Ili region from 1770 to 2005. Chen et al. (2008a) developed a reconstruction of annual precipitation (July–June) for the last 301 years for Eastern Tian Shan (Qitai and Mulei) in north Xinjiang. For better visual comparison, all reconstructions were scaled to a mean of zero and smoothed with a 10 yr low-pass filter to highlight low-frequency climate signals (Figure 7). Most of the correlation coefficients between our PDSI reconstruction and other proxy records of Tian Shan are significant at the 1% level. Our new reconstruction shows similar wet/dry periods to the other proxy records. Regional dry conditions during ad 1697–1721, 1741–1752, 1805–1825, 1853–1878, 1908–1932 and 1973–1988 and wet conditions during ad 1722–1740, 1826–1852, 1879–1907, 1933–1950 and 1989–2006 found in this study synchronously occurred in other regions of Tian Shan. Reconstructed and inferred dry periods correspond with cold periods over the past several hundred years. The drying of the late 1600s to early 1700s, seen in the drought reconstruction, coincides with cooler conditions resulting from low solar activity in the Maunder minimum (Eddy, 1976). The drying of the 1800s to early 1820s seen in the reconstructions coincides with cooler conditions resulting from a series of tropical eruptions (1808–1815), which likely resulted in an aerosol-accumulated summer cooling effect (Chenoweth, 2001; Dai et al., 1991). In Tian Shan, the driest period during the 20th century occurred during 1908–1932. This drought appears to have occurred over a large geographic area, as it has also been evidenced by many studies over the surrounding regions (Li et al., 2007; Liang et al., 2003; Pederson et al., 2001). In particular, the reconstructions of Tian Shan exhibit a upward trend during 1989–2005, implying that a moisture increase in Tian Shan brought by the Westerlies contrasts with a consistent moisture decrease in the Qilian mountains due to declining intensity of the Asia summer monsoon (Yang et al., 2011). Some studies suggest the contrasting trend in moisture variation may be linked with the interactions between the monsoon system and westerly system (Chen HF et al., 2008b; Yang et al., 2011). However, this relationship is not always stable at multicentury scales in the tree-ring based reconstructions, and ring width series of Tian Shan shows similar dry periods to tree ring width series of the Qilian mountains (Chen et al., 2011a), and some extreme drought events (i.e. 1810, 1916–1917, 1944–1946 and 1923–1932) were also found in the two regions. Our PDSI reconstruction showed that the ‘Little Ice Age’ was a relatively wet period in Western Tian Shan. This may be linked with the high SSTs of the Atlantic Oceans and positive NAO (Figures 8 and 9). A study also argued that extreme drought events linked with a significant La Niña event and cooler SSTs may have broad implications in relation to the influence of tropical climate on remote central Asia (Li et al., 2010). However, other studies showed that the relatively high humidity during the ‘Little Ice Age’ in northwest China possibly results from the increase of precipitation in this region due to the southward shift of westerly (negative NAO) and the decrease of evapotranspiration caused by the cooling during that time (Hurrell and Van Loon, 1997; Chen JH et al., 2008c). Thus, the mechanism how these circulation systems and factors interact and how they control regional moisture variability at various timescales awaits further investigation.

sec.title: Linkages with the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans
sec.p: The spatial correlation analysis shows that our reconstruction captures a great part of the regional drought variability of Western Tian Shan (Figure 8a). It is also found that the PDSI reconstruction correlates significantly with the gridded surface precipitation (January–May) and shows very similar spatial correlation fields (Figure 8b). High frequency peaks in 2–5 years were also found in the neighboring moisture-related tree-ring reconstructions in Xinjiang and the vicinity (Chen et al., 2009, 2011a, 2011b; Fang et al., 2010; Gou et al., 2007). These high-frequency cycles and the multidecadal cycle (60.2 years) fall within the overall bandwidth of the winter North Atlantic Oscillation (WNAO, Glueck and Stockton, 2001), suggesting the influence of the North Atlantic Oscillation on the climate of Central Asia. The significant positive correlations of the reconstructed PDSI with sea surface temperature (SST) in the North Atlantic Ocean support such a connection (Figure 8c). Using the instrumental records, a possible mechanism was proposed for the positive correlations of the precipitation in Xinjiang with the SSTs in the Indo-Atlantic Ocean (Yang and Shi, 2002; Yang et al., 2010a). Increased precipitation in Northern Xinjiang was associated with stronger westerly winds during the period of high sea surface temperature (Yang et al., 2010b). Positive North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) conditions cause the Icelandic Low to draw a stronger southwesterly flow of air over Asia, preventing Arctic air from plunging southward. In contrast, if the difference in sea-level pressure between Iceland and the Azores is small (negative NAO), westerly winds are suppressed, allowing Arctic dry air to spill southwards into Asia more readily (Folland et al., 2009; Glueck and Stockton, 2001; Jones and Conway, 1997). Comparison of the 15 yr low-pass filtered PDSI reconstruction of Western Tian Shan with the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation reconstruction (AMO, Gray et al., 2004) since ad 1580 reveals a close relationship (r = 0.32, P < 0.001, Figure 9a). Detailed analysis suggests several wet years following a primarily positive AMO year, and the mean of January–May PDSI of positive AMO years is 0.31 higher than negative AMO years. As shown in Figure 9b, our drought reconstruction agrees with the reconstructed AMO variation, i.e. the periods ad 1580–1601, 1620–1644, 1657–1674, 1686–1707, 1722–1735, 1755–1776, 1795–1821, 1829–1847, 1867–1889, 1898–1910, 1922–1941, 1963–1972 and 1980–1990. As discussed above, moisture conditions in Central Asia are related to the Westerly circulation which is influenced by the North Atlantic Oceans at long timescales.

These high-frequency cycles also fall within the overall bandwidth of El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO, Allan et al., 1996), suggesting a possible teleconnection of regional drought variability in Central Asia with the tropical ocean–atmosphere systems. Our reconstructed droughts are significantly correlated with sea surface temperature in the Indo–West Pacific Oceans. Some droughts in central Asia were associated with the unusual cooling of SSTs (La Niña-like conditions) in the Indian Ocean, particularly in the Arabian Sea (Barlow et al., 2002; Hoerling and Kumar, 2003; Li et al., 2010). As shown in Mariotti (2007), enhanced precipitation in central Asia during warm ENSO events results from an anomalous southwesterly moisture flux coming from the Arabian Sea and tropical Africa, which is generated along the northwestern flank of the high pressure anomaly over the Indian and western Pacific Oceans (Mariotti, 2007). The enhanced southwesterly moisture flux brings abundant moisture across the Arabian Peninsula and travels further northward, causing increased precipitation over central Asia (Mariotti, 2007; Yang et al., 2010c). The southwesterly moisture flux was reduced during La Niña events, resulting in droughts in central Asia. These impacts on pressure and circulation persist throughout the year (Mariotti, 2007). Significant positive correlations between the PDSI and the Indo–West Pacific Oceans SSTs at decadal scale further suggested the influence of the tropical ocean–atmosphere systems on regional droughts in our study area.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A Picea schrenkiana tree-ring width chronology spanning 1580–2006 was developed for Western Tian Shan, Central Asia. The January–May PDSI reconstruction explained 35% of the variance of the instrumental PDSI during the period 1925–2005. Our PDSI reconstruction of Western Tian Shan is likely representative of moisture variability over a large region along the Tian Shan Range. The reconstruction revealed that dry intervals occurred during ad 1614–1628, 1700–1722, 1758–1790, 1806–1833, 1873–1898, 1908–1936, 1943–1951, 1960–1966 and 1973–1988, and wet intervals in ad 1580–1613, 1629–1699, 1723–1757, 1791–1805, 1834–1872, 1899–1907, 1937–1942, 1952–1959, 1967–1972 and 1989–present. Comparison with other records shows high coherency in the timing of dry/wet intervals at the decadal scale across Tian Shan. A trend of increasing moisture under global warming in the late 20th century is showed in our PDSI reconstruction. The severe drought in 1917 is most extreme for Western Tian Shan during the last 426 years.

Significant spectral peaks were found at 2–5 years, which all fall within the bandwidths for ENSO and WNAO. We found the significant correlations of regional droughts in Western Tian Shan with SST were found in the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans. The spatial correlation patterns with the North Atlantic and Indo–West Pacific Oceans suggest linkages of regional moisture variability with the westerly circulation and tropical ocean–atmosphere systems.

Our results are preliminary and require confirmation from further dendroclimatological studies of Central Asia. Continued work in this direction should enable us to understand better the nature of drought and rainfall in and around Central Asia.
